The '''University of New Haven''' is a private university that combines a liberal arts education with professional training. The [[university]] comprises five colleges: the College of Arts and Sciences, the College of Business, the Tagliatela College of Engineering, the Henry C. Lee College of Criminal Justice and Forensic Sciences, and University College for adult students.<ref>{{cite web|title=Academics|url=http://www.newhaven.edu/academics/|work=newhaven.edu}}</ref>
Founded in 1920, the university is located in [[West Haven, Connecticut]], which borders the larger city of [[New Haven]] and [[Long Island Sound]]. In the five years leading up to 2011 the universityâs [[undergraduate]] and [[graduate]] student enrollment increased by 28% and as of fall 2011 totals over 6,000 students.
The University is a member of the [[Northeast-10 Conference]] and its mascot is the [[Horses in warfare#Europe|Charger]], a medieval war horse. In 2008-2009, new student applications increased 100 percent.<ref>[http://www.newhaven.edu/news-archive/22612/ Application Increase]</ref> New facilities, including the David A. Beckerman Recreation Center, the new $46 million Soundview residence hall, and the Henry C. Lee Institute of Forensic Science which opened in 2010.<ref>[http://www.newhavenregister.com/articles/2009/03/06/news/new_haven/a1_--_henrylee.txt Henry C. Lee Institute of Forensic Science]</ref>
Situated on 84 acres overlooking the [[Connecticut]] shoreline the main campus is 90 minutes by train to [[New York City]] and 2 Â½ hours from [[Boston]]. Five satellite campuses are located in: * [[New London, Connecticut|New London, CT]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Southeastern Campus|url=http://www.newhaven.edu/admissions/gradadmissions/sect/|work=newhaven.edu}}</ref> * [[Waterbury, Connecticut|Waterbury, CT]] * [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton, CT]] * [[Newington, Connecticut|Newington, CT]] * [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque, NM]]
U.S. News & World Report magazine has named the university the 110th best regional university in the Northern United States in its annual "America's Best Colleges" rankings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Regional University North Rankings|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/regional-universities-north/spp%2B50/page+3|work=usnews.com}}</ref>
==Academic Overview== Approximately 33% of students are enrolled in [[College of Arts and Sciences|arts and sciences]], 21% in [[business]], 12% in [[engineering]], and 34% in [[criminal justice]] and [[Forensic science|forensic sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|title=University Statistics|url=http://www.newhaven.edu/about/133705/|work=http://www.newhaven.com}}</ref>
A number of the universityâs undergraduate degree programs have been nationally recognized, most notably the nationally accredited [[engineering]] programs, [[forensic science]], marine biology, and music and sound recording, as well as music industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=www.intelligentgulf.com|url=http://www.intelligentgulf.com/student-service/student-scholarships/university-new-haven.html|work=University of New Haven Degree Programs}}</ref> The College of Arts and Sciences Theater program has been selected to host the [[Kennedy Center American College Theater Festival]] in January 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=www.chargerbulletin.com|url=http://www.chargerbulletin.com/2010/02/17/kennedy-festival-offers-students-opportunity/{{!}}date=August 2011|work=University Theater Department}}</ref>
==Student organizations==
===''Charger Bulletin''=== {{main|Charger Bulletin}} The ''Charger Bulletin'' is a student-run [[newspaper]] published by students at the University of New Haven in [[West Haven, Connecticut]] since 1938.
===WNHU=== {{main|WNHU}} The University's non-commercial radio station, [[WNHU]]-FM, first signed onto the air at 1600 EDT on July 4, 1973. WNHU is broadcast on 88.7 FM. WNHU is acclaimed by many as the best college radio station in the [[state of Connecticut]], {{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} and has won the New Haven Advocate award for Best College Radio station for over 4 consecutive years.{{when?|date=November 2011}}{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}
